Tricksters
So, I'm going to preface this by saying that the fact that you need to read this faq means a decent chance that you're screwed. I'm sorry, it's just a fact of life. This guide will help you to either maximize what little time you have left, or learn about preventing tricksters from attacking.
So what is a trickster?
Tricksters are probably the single most chaotic and malevolent entity that sburb can possibly produce. Seriously. A trickster can tank the black king, the black queen, hell, it could probably kill a debug NPC if it felt like it.
Why wouldn't I want to be a Trickster, then?
Imagine if you will looking out in horror as your skin turns to sugar and your brains into candy, as even as you speak your words become saccharine and your thoughts go mad, and you want it off but you can't resist it. If the answer to any of these questions was a yes, then get some help. If you are a trickster, you are not you. Tricksters care only about candy, "fun", and reproduction. If you manage to become one, any goals or relationships you had before you did are screwed.
How do you become one?
This is one that I really, really hesitate to answer. For the sake of avoidance, however, I will. In order to become a trickster, you need something with a certain intrinsic quality. We don't really know what it is, or what this quality is, only that it exists. My guess is that it's always candy, but I may be wrong. Ours was a massive jawbreaker. It had this sort of red and green swirl pattern, and the temptation of eating it was irresistible. You just have to eat it, or do whatever your body instinctively does when it touches the item. Other than that, just let yourself get kissed, kicked in the genitals, or something else weird by the trickster(s).
What can a trickster do?
Tricksters can do essentially anything. They can fly, create life, alchemize without grist, create grist, are basically invulnerable, have pretty much infinite strength and endurance, massive speed, know exactly what to say to hurt you, and are completely insane. They can do other stuff if they feel like it. One guy got trapped in a sort of infinite loop within a santa doll. He eventually went trickster, and the rest is history.
How do you stop them?
There are pretty much two ways to stop a trickster from attacking you. Death doesn't work, they'll just resurrect you, and god tiers can only hold them off for so long. No, the only ways to stop them are with a) a Zillyweapon, or b) outside interference. The first can be very rarely found through temporal shenanigans or normal quests, or through usage of the grist that tricksters secrete(?) called Zillium. Zillium can make Zillyweapons and some other weird stuff, which is all insanely strong. The weapons won't corrupt you, but too much zillium can, and it can be used to make a trickster item. Be on your toes if you ever find any. The outside interference part I've only heard about. Supposedly, some sort of outside force can end trickster corruption for good through time travel (not loops) or cleansing or something. Don't bet on that happening, though.
Recognizing a trickster
Tricksters have bright, neon hair and clothes, are covered in candy, weird skin (it disobeys the laws of reality somehow), and talk in a voice that can't be replicated. They will talk in a sugary sweet, sexually perverse, creepy as hell way. If you can see it, it can probably see you. Say your prayers.
In conclusion
Tricksters are undoubtedly a huge threat. Luckily, they're very rare and don't focus at all on finishing the game. If either of those were to be false, we'd be screwed. If you suspect someone of being a trickster, stay away, tell your friends to stay away, as well as any pets you may have. Try to get a Zillyweapon. Other than that, just pray that you don't get found.

Help! Meteors are falling everywhere! How do I get in this game already! First off, dying from a meteor is probably better than being in this game, but if you really want to, get your server player to place down the free buildings, the Cruxtruder, Punch Designex, Totem lathe, and Alchemiter, along with the pre-punched card. With all of those placed down, you need to open up the Cruxtruder, which requires a lot of force, so get your server player to drop something heavy on it, that usually works. A long cylinder should come out, along with some glowy flashy sphere and a countdown on the Cruxtruder.The countdown is how long you have to do all these random things until your death by fiery meteor, that cylinder is called a Cruxite Dowel, and the flashy thing is the Kernelsprite. Make sure you toss something into that thing before you enter the session, preferably NOT something extremely powerful, or else your session is screwed before you even start. I know this is really tedious, but next, take that Dowel and the Pre-Punched card and stick them into the Totem Lathe. That should cut the dowel into a new shape, the Cruxite Totem, which you can put into the Alchemiter to get some sort of Cruxite Artifact, which is different for each person. Using or doing whatever the Artifact wants you to do will put you into the session. Good luck.

I've just installed SBURB, but its not doing anything.
SBURB isn't a game you can play alone*. Once installed, you can choose to either play as a Server or a Client player. It doesn't matter which you choose. You'll eventually play both, whether you like it or not.
*typically. Some people claim that it's been done before. Probably just another bogus rumor, though. I wouldn't try it.
What is the difference between a Server and a Client player?
It's actually pretty self explanitory. A Server player Hosts a Client Player in a session. The Client player connects to a Server Player. What ISN'T self explanitory is the duties of both players; A Server Player is required to add constructions and modify the Client Player's home in order to prepare them for entry into their Session. Meanwhile, it's the Client Player's duty to actually enter.
Alright, I'm a Server Player. Now what?
Once your Client connects, you should be able to see them on your screen along with menus for adding constructions. There's a few objects you'll want to add as soon as possible. The Cruxtruder, The Alchemiter, the Totem Lathe, the Punch Designix and the Pre-Punched Card are the most important. They should be free to build, but the more Clients and Servers you have connected to your session, the more objects and add-ons will be available. For now, just focus on placing the objects listed above and get ready for the game to begin.
My player's room is too small! I can't put all this stuff in here!
Remember when I said you can modify the player's home? You can do that. From the Menus, you should be able to select the option to create more rooms. Just click and drag where you want to expand and viola. More floorspace! The walls and ceilings will adjust to fit, so don't worry about that. You can also add and remove doors, windows, stairs, and walkways! Pesky Furniture in the way? Click and drag it to another room! Toss it on the roof, who cares? I'm sure that priceless family portrait would look great hanging on the front door.
I've placed the Cruxtruder, but it's not doing anything? What's the point of this big stupid thing!
Did you also place the Alchemiter, Totem Lathe, Punch Designix, and the Pre-Punched Card? If no, DON'T TOUCH THAT YET. If yes, then strap in. Shit is about to get real! The Cruxtruder can be opened by applying significant force to the cap on the top of that little pipe jutting up from the center of the machine. Once you pop the lid on that soda-can, a couple things will fly free: The Cruxite Dowel and the Kernel Sprite*. Have your player take that Dowel and bring it to the Totem Lathe.
*more on that later
The Totem Lathe looks like something I saw on TV...
It's a Lathe. It carves Totems. In SBURB, Totems act like 3D Barcodes for the Alchemiter to create objects with. There should be a Punch Card Slot on the side of the machine. Instruct your player to place the Dowel on the Lathe and insert the Pre Punched Card into the slot. The Lathe will carve the Dowel for you to use on the Alchemiter. Oh, and seriously insist on your player hurrying up. You have more important things to worry about than carving tons of totems right now.
The Alchemiter looks neat. How do I use it?
The Alchemiter is the machine that will allow you to create items and objects to be used in SBURB! There should be a pedestal with a weird geometrical design on it. If you place any carved Dowels on that pedestal, the Alchemiter will scan it and create the object designated by the Dowel's shape. Each Dowel is unique, based on the Punch Card used to make it. Tell your player to put the Dowel you made using the Pre Punched Card on it and get ready to enter.

You can only prototype a sprite twice, so make it count. Some people like to toss in meaningful things, and others just toss in whatever. It really doesn't matter, just so long as you actually do it. You MUST prototype the Kernel at least ONCE before you enter though, or else the game is going to go bonkers. You can do it twice before entry too, but I hear it makes the game harder...

OH NO: I really, really, really don't feel like playing this game anymore.
Unfortunately for you, there are only two ways out of this.
1: Win. 2: Die.
I'm not sure if you've tried to take the second way out, but it doesn't work. Not as long as you want it. So you have to play, because it's the only thing you can do, and if you don't, then the game has plenty worse ways to make you suffer other than death.
OH NO: Why should I keep playing this game? I'm struggling to find a meaning.
Don't want to spoil it for you, but if all goes as planned, this game's ending will be the best of any game you've ever played. Except, well, it's not really a game. What you need to know is that if you decide to give up now, you will just let yourself down, you will let everyone else down. The very nature of the game requires that all players cooperate toward achieving a singular goal or else chaos ensues. By giving up, you are essentially giving the biggest middle finger possible to everyone else in the game.
OH NO: Why should I care about playing if all my friends are dead?
Frankly, depending on how far you got before this happened, you don't have much a chance at winning the game. One option is that you're in a doomed timeline, and in that case, there isn't much you can do. I've heard some people try talking to their Denizen, if it's still alive, and it can rarely provide you with an option that will help out some other instance of you in another frame of existence.
However, in the event that you're not in a doomed timeline... well, sucks to be you, eh? Better find something to occupy your time, because you're likely to have a lot of it. It's not forever, oh no, trust me, but you're going to need to find something to keep your mind busy, fast.
Most people just do bike stunts.
OH NO: I'm the last living player and am getting kind of bored of bike stunts. What now?
First of all, no one can ever get bored of bike stunts. Ever. That's just a thing that doesn't happen.
In the event that you have managed to get bored of bike stunts, congratulations. You're a statistical anomaly. Now, I hate to break it to you, but yeah, you don't have forever. Eventually an event called the Reckoning will occur, and all those meteors floating in Derse's orbit will start flying toward Skaia. Since you're the last one alive, it's pointless for me to tell you why this is happening and what it means.
What is important, however, is that by the Reckoning's end, Skaia is destroyed, including the Battlefield. If you had maybe a 0.0001% chance of victory before, it's 0% now. You cannot win without Skaia. The Army of Darkness has succeeded in their mission, however suicidal it may have been.
However, basically unknown to anyone at all (trust me, you won't find much about this any of Prospit, Derse, or your land's libraries) is that at the center of the Battlefield, far beneath its chessboard surface, there is a bomb. It varies in size from session to session and doesn't seem to correlate to any known variables. In some sessions it can fit in the palm of your hands, in others it's the size of a skyscraper. Regardless of size, this bomb is powerful enough to completely obliterate your session. It will go off as soon as the game detects that the Reckoning is complete.
In short, you're done for. No way around that.
OH NO: I've some how come into possession into a weird ying-yang looking thing that was found in the center of the Battlefield. What do I do?
Well, that ying-yang looking thing is the most lethal bomb known to man, consort, and carapace. Don't try using it, or alchemizing it into anything, because it never ends well. This bomb is designed to completely obliterate your session and everyone in it should things ever go awry. So yeah. You're better off just leaving that thing where you found it, because you wouldn't want to set it off accidentally, would you?
Now, I have heard rumors of ways to dispose of this bomb, but no matter how hard you try, this thing will inevitably detonate. That doesn't mean it has to detonate inside your session, however. I once heard a story about a group of players who took the bomb, put it on a Skaian Battleship, then flung that thing Out of Bounds. I'm not sure what happened after that, but I assume that the bomb must have exploded somewhere in deep space, or some unlucky kids got a face full of session-shattering-kaboom. Either way, the group that did the disposing never had to worry about the bomb ever again.
Oh yeah, and that group may have been mine, and that story may have been on the wall in one of the ruins on my Land. Prophecies, eh? Gotta love 'em.
(edited)
OH NO: I just saw a painting of a bunch of dead kids somewhere on my land! What does this mean?
Well, clearly it means that a bunch of kids are going to die in your session. Them's the breaks. However, a lot of the time these paintings, engravings, or statues, however they may appear, are intentionally vague. Sure, a bunch of kids are going to die in your session, but maybe they're not your players. Maybe some other players show up, and all get slaughtered by whatever it is that lives beyond the session's boundaries just minutes before crossing it.
So please, do remember to analyze your prophecies carefully. Or, you could just ask a Seer, or a Hero of Doom.
OH NO: Oh my god, they're dead. They can come back, right? Right? Oh my god, please tell me that they can come back! If you haven't kissed them yet, do it now. If you die in the game, you die in real life.
OH NO: I just kissed my dead friend and they're like, flying or something now. What happened? Standard kiss revival procedure. In layman's terms, their dreamself has merged with their real self. The only real difference this makes is that they can fly now, and also one other thing, but I'm not quite going to spoil that for you. Everybody gets one.
OH NO: I just kissed my dead friend and nothing happened! What's this all about? Hate to break it to you, but there's a 97% chance that you're friend is perma-dead. Unfortunately there's very little you can do about that now, unless you somehow have acquired the power to bring back the dead. Ask a life player.
OH NO: So... my friend is dead. Forever. They're not coming back. Why should I continue? Take a deep breath. Count to 10. Whisper this to yourself. "The game must go on." SBURB stops for no one. It will not stop for the deaths of your players, and it will not stop to let you grieve about it. Refusing to play is a one-way ticket to Deathville, population: you. It sounds wrong, but the best thing to do is to forget about your friend and keep playing the game. There will be plenty of time to grieve when it's over.

Question: I've heard a few things about getting consort companions. How would I go about doing that?
That's a great question. As a Hero of Blood, your powers will be put to their best use when in charge of a group. Whether this group be consorts, players, hired underlings, or carapacians, you're the best. If you've sufficiently advanced along your quest, most consorts will recognize you as being the hero of the land. Some may ask for you to complete a quest first, but none of these quests are too hard. The problem is that not all consorts who are easy to find are the best for your party. Sure, you could lead a party of a thousand weak consorts, but as a group gets larger it also becomes harder to manage. You'll want to look for rare consorts with special titles. Those guys can dish out insane amounts of damage that is only further multiplied by your powers.
